text:
Hello everybody. I'm on a such dilemma and I'd be really grateful if you could share some experiences.
The higher-ups suddendly came to me asking for *specific numbers we should* reach with our organic channels, such as the blog traffic, social media engagement and followers, etc.
The thing is, I've been trying to tell them it's not that simple (specially because we are not running paid ads this quarter). I've been trying to solve this with our head of social media and SEO and they told me exactly the same I've been thinking: it depends so much.
Has someone been on this situation? Did you do something to solve this?

text: Thanks for the article, <@U02A8UR3Z60>! Very helpful.
I got asked this all the time (for years) so I've started mapping this out in Google data studio and the traffic projections are pretty valuable and helpful.

elements.text: I got asked this all the time (for years) so I've started mapping this out in Google data studio and the traffic projections are pretty valuable and helpful.

text:
Hi, Camila! I was just working on something like this yesterday! At my company, we're in the midst of our budget cycle now. In my budget presentation, I will have to discuss our organic traffic historical results, what progress we've made since we re-engaged our SEO agency a few months ago, what I expect we can achieve by the end of this fiscal year, and what I think we could hit next fiscal year. So I pulled data from our Google Analytics and created a spreadsheet with a pivot line chart to plot our fiscal year organic traffic from two years ago, last year, this year so far, and projections for the rest of this year and all of next year (projections are in dotted lines). Our site traffic is very cyclical, so I've plotted it out by month to show our traffic for each fiscal year, e.g., comparing Dec 2019 vs Dec 2020 vs Dec 2021. Knowing which months are typically higher or lower helped me estimate what I think our future results realistically could be if we continue our SEO work. 

My budget request is to make the case for securing funds again to keep our engagement with our SEO agency partner, so I need to demonstrate that the work we've done so far is showing improvement already YoY, and that we can't afford to not keep spending money on this critical task. 

As you're thinking about the traffic data you're pulling together and all of your "it depends" factors, think about the story you need to tell to make your point. I highly recommend "Storytelling With Data: A Data Visualization Guide for Business Professionals" by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic. That book will help you think about how to boil down your data to visually tell the story you need to tell to your audience to provide context and get them to focus on what matters.

text:
Thank you both! I read recently in some other thread about someone doing forecasts with data visualization and I think you made an excellent point with that <@U031B8HB5FB>. Specially because using graphics could help people with little knowledge to understand how it works and how it moves. I'll look for that book definitely.
Thank you so much for those insights :pray:
